meta.title: Code Blue
meta.notes: Rewrite S01–S10. Slow burn. Behavioral choices. Replay-focused.

S01.text:
Dr. Adrian Cole stands just inside the ER doors, badge still stiff against his chest.

The place is louder than he imagined. Not screaming—constant motion. Monitors chirping, stretchers rolling, voices overlapping like no one ever finishes a sentence.

A senior resident moves through it all without breaking stride, issuing orders that land instantly. An ER nurse catches a falling chart with her foot and doesn’t even look down. Down the hall, another intern laughs too loudly, already at ease.

No one stops to welcome you. No one should.

You’re expected to step in.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Shadow the resident** — You stick close to the senior resident, watching how she commands the room and hoping you don’t get in her way.
2) **Help the nurse** — You jump in with the ER nurse, taking whatever task she throws at you, no questions asked.
3) **Match the intern** — You fall in alongside the other intern, keeping pace so you’re not the weakest link.
4) **Stick to protocol** — You start with charts and procedures, choosing safety over visibility.

S02.text:
The senior resident doesn’t acknowledge you at first. She just hands you a chart mid-stride.

You skim it while walking. She’s fast. Efficient. Every decision sharp enough to cut.

At one point she glances back. Not to check your work—just to see if you’re still there.

“You keeping up?” she asks.

It’s not unkind. It’s a filter.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Keep pace** — You don’t slow her down, even if it means guessing once or twice.
2) **Ask clarification** — You risk looking green to make sure you’re right.
3) **Take initiative** — You suggest a next step before she asks.
4) **Stay quiet** — You observe and learn without drawing attention.

S03.text:
The ER nurse sizes you up in half a second.

“Intern,” she says, already moving. “Gloves. Gauze. Try not to faint.”

She works fast, talking the patient down while doing three things at once. At one point she mutters, “They never teach this part in med school,” and snorts.

You notice a small charting shortcut—nothing dangerous, but not strictly by the book.

She notices you noticing.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Cover for her** — You quietly fix the charting later instead of pointing it out.
2) **Say something** — You flag the issue now, even if it slows things down.
3) **Let it go** — You pretend you didn’t see it.
4) **Ask about it** — You question her privately, not publicly.

S04.text:
The other intern grins when he sees you fall into step.

“First shift?” he asks, already answering his own question. “Relax. They eat the nervous ones.”

He rattles off a diagnosis a little too loudly. It’s mostly right—but not complete.

People nearby hear it. Including an attending.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Correct him quietly** — You pull him aside before it becomes a problem.
2) **Let him run** — If he’s wrong, he’ll learn.
3) **Outperform him** — You jump in with a better answer.
4) **Back him up** — You support his call, even with doubts.

S05.text:
You choose caution.

Protocols. Checklists. Paperwork.

No one criticizes you for it. No one praises you either.

From the sidelines, you notice patterns—who bends rules, who enforces them, who pretends not to see either.

Being invisible feels safe.

It also feels temporary.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Step in now** — You decide it’s time to be seen.
2) **Keep observing** — Information is power.
3) **Align with someone** — You choose a side.
4) **Stay neutral** — You protect yourself.

S06.text:
The case escalates fast.

Orders overlap. Someone swears. A monitor alarm screams until it’s silenced.

You act.

Not perfectly—but decisively.

The patient stabilizes.

Later, adrenaline lingers in the break room. So does tension. People remember who helped and how.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Debrief openly** — You talk through what happened with the team.
2) **Thank someone** — You acknowledge specific help.
3) **Deflect credit** — You push attention away from yourself.
4) **Say nothing** — You let the moment pass.

S07.text:
The resident closes the door behind you.

“Don’t do that again,” she says. Then pauses. “Actually… do. Just warn me first.”

It’s the closest thing to praise she gives.

She studies you for a moment longer than necessary.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Acknowledge trust** — You tell her you won’t let her down.
2) **Keep it professional** — You steer away from subtext.
3) **Test the moment** — You let the silence linger.
4) **Change subject** — You break the tension.

S08.text:
The nurse catches you near the supply room.

“Thanks,” she says. Not loud. Not performative.

Then, with a smirk: “Just don’t make a habit of it.”

You’re not sure if she means the shortcut—or helping her.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Play it off** — You joke and move on.
2) **Acknowledge risk** — You admit it could’ve gone wrong.
3) **Ask her out** — Just coffee. Nothing serious.
4) **Set boundary** — You keep things clean.

S09.text:
Your rival doesn’t appreciate being shown up.

He laughs it off in public. His eyes don’t.

You’ve made an impression. Whether that’s good or bad depends on who’s watching.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Stand by it** — You don’t apologize for being right.
2) **Smooth things over** — You talk privately.
3) **Blame pressure** — You deflect responsibility.
4) **Escalate** — You bring it to a superior.

S10.text:
Your shift ends, but the hospital doesn’t let go that easily.

Names stick. Moments linger.

You don’t know yet which choices mattered most.

But you will.

---

**CHOICES**
1) **Stay late** — You stick around and see what unfolds.
2) **Leave now** — You go home and reset.
3) **Check messages** — You see who reached out.
4) **Reflect quietly** — You take stock before acting.
